entry.title: PathCoin
entry.summary:
AdamISZ introduces a unique concept that imagines the possibility of sending a coin in a manner akin to an email, essentially transferring data directly to another party without the conventional necessity for broader network interaction. He acknowledges from the outset that this idea faces significant challenges and might seem entirely impractical under normal circumstances. However, by applying certain restrictions and assumptions, he outlines a theoretical model for achieving this feat through a detailed explanation provided in a [gist](https://gist.github.com/AdamISZ/b462838cbc8cc06aae0c15610502e4da). In this model, he suggests the use of signature adaptors and CTV or similar covenants as mechanisms to enable a trustless transfer of control over a utxo (unspent transaction output) directly between two parties. This process would require an extensive one-time setup but aims to eliminate the need for interaction with any third party at the time of the actual transfer.
Despite the innovative approach, AdamISZ is candid about the severe limitations inherent to his proposal. He successfully addresses one of these limitations within his written explanation but openly admits to not overcoming several others. Moreover, he briefly contrasts his idea with existing concepts such as statechains and payment pools, which make different trade-offs to achieve somewhat related goals. He does not claim that his 'pathcoin' idea is currently viable or superior to these alternatives but rather presents it as a thought experiment that could spark further development among creative minds in the field.
By publishing his thoughts and the accompanying technical breakdown, AdamISZ invites others in the community to engage with, critique, and possibly advance his initial framework. His proposal stands as an invitation to imaginative individuals who may see potential in his concept and are inspired to explore its possibilities further.
